awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Controlled Sensing with Social Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:  This research addresses the growing need for new techniques in controlled sensing and information fusion with social sensors. Social sensors learn from and interact with  each other  over a social network to estimate an underlying state  - the process is called social learning. The aim of this research is to develop mathematical models,  algorithms and analysis for controlled sensing and information  fusion  with social learning. Controlled sensing with social learning is a first step towards constructing generative feedback models and algorithms in the data science of social networks. Similar formulations arise in multi-agent signal processing problems  where automated decision makers interact to achieve a sensing goal. The research transcends classical statistical signal processing (which deals with extracting signals from noisy measurements) to address the deeper issue of how multi-agent decision systems and signal processing algorithms interact.

The objectives of this research  fall under two inter-related themes:  Bayesian social learning where quickest change detection and controlled fusion are considered; and interactive sensing in large scale networks where adaptive estimation of degree distribution dynamics, infection dynamics and posterior Cramer Rao bounds are considered. The research involves the interplay of Bayesian social learning, stochastic control and mean field dynamics.  The key unifying themes underpinning this research  are statistical signal processing and controlled sensing. Social learning involves myopic decision making by individual agents; while controlled sensing involves stochastic control over a time horizon. This interaction between myopic social sensors (local decision makers) and a non-myopic controller (global decision maker) results in unusual behavior. The scientific innovation of this research stems from advancing deep results in Bayesian estimation, stochastic optimization, weak convergence analysis, and lattice programming.

por.por_cntn:
This project has contributed to understanding the interaction between statistical signal processing and behavioral economics, that is, how human decision makers (called social sensors) interact with signals and physical sensors. While signal processing and behavioral economics are mature areas, their intersection is still in its infancy. Yet advances in the area will contribute to the design of next generation human-sensor interface systems.
Social sensors are agents that provide information about their environment (state) to a social network after interaction with other social sensors; this information fusion is modeled by social learning, namely how agents learn from their previous decisions and the decisions of other agents.The project has developed  novel mathematical models, structural results and algorithms for controlled sensing with social learning. Specifically the project has contributed to two important inter-related themes:
First, the project has investigated how risk averse behavior in social learning affects statistical detection problems such as  quickest change detection. We have contributed to mathematical methods for pricing  information in data fusion, and how the convergence rate of Bayesian  estimation algorithms is affected by social learning. The results developed in the project yield fundamental bounds on the optimal performance, give insight into what parameters affect the optimal sensing strategies, and yield computationally efficient algorithms.
Second,  the project has contributed to  the statistical signal processing of social sensors that interact on large (possibly random) graphs. The project has developed novel algorithms that adaptively estimate the degree distribution of evolving random social networks, and also investigated fundamental statistical bounds on how accurately various parameters of information diffusion in a social network can be estimated.  

The contributions of this project have been disseminated as publications in archival journals and conferences. From a technological point of view, the deeper mathematical methods and algorithms developed have also contributed to areas outside this project such as the design of sophisticated sensing and radar systems in collaboration with industrial partners and government laboratories.
